page.title: 11SPEKE HALL (continued)
page.content: ..introduced by Watt and the two blend well. Speke Hall is full of interesting features such as the moulded 17th century ceiling of the great parlour, priest holes, tapestries and interesting furniture. An Elizabethan stone bridge leads to the "black and white" house and the courtyard. The National Trust took over the hall in 1942, and it is administered by the Merseyside County Museums.Although the hall is still surrounded by trees and parkland open to the public, it now stands on the edge of Liverpool Airport which causes some concern with the vibration of 'planes. It is close to Speke Industrial Estate,as the city of Liverpool has expanded towards the hall. Written by C.H.Elwood and class 4E Stocktonwood Juniors
